subject: Do JUnit internals suck?!?
msgSnippet: Below is a brief conversation that took place on another mailing list.  The original comment by DS was in response to another person s question regarding
messageBody:
Below is a brief conversation that took place on another mailing list. The
original comment by DS was in response to another person's question
regarding problems using JUnit for testing EJBs. My text is marked with my
initials, CD. While I will take the advice of DS and have a look at the
source, I wanted the group to have access to his opinion, to have feedback
that could be used to make JUnit better for the next release.

DS > Junit internals suck. I would love to rewrite it, but don't
DS > have the time.

CD > I've been told before that the JUnit source code serves as a great
CD > example for writing good code. Hence, your statement surprised me.
CD > Since you're a respected developer of a great application server, I
CD > ask that you cite a few examples to support your statement. I'd
CD > really like to hear your side of the story.

DS > Read the source, and you will see what I am talking about. I believe
DS > you misunderstood the comments from other people. JUnit is a good
DS > example of successful software development and it is also a good
example
DS > of XP development. The problem with XP is that it is not designed for
DS > Library software (see the last chapter of the xp book), so it works
good
DS > at what it was designed for, but it is difficult to expand. They also
DS > use way too much inheritance and not enough interfaces. Anyway, just
DS > read the code and be the judge for yourself.

<<<<<<<<<<<<< >>>>>>>>>>>>>
Craig Demyanovich
Systems Developer
Apogent Technologies
